source.0b8b57d8:
daily_activity <- read_csv("../input/fitbit/Fitabase Data 4.12.16-5.12.16/dailyActivity_merged.csv")
hourly_calories <- read_csv("../input/fitbit/Fitabase Data 4.12.16-5.12.16/hourlyCalories_merged.csv")
hourly_intensities <- read_csv("../input/fitbit/Fitabase Data 4.12.16-5.12.16/hourlyIntensities_merged.csv")
sleep_day <- read_csv("../input/fitbit/Fitabase Data 4.12.16-5.12.16/sleepDay_merged.csv")
weight_log_info <- read_csv("../input/fitbit/Fitabase Data 4.12.16-5.12.16/weightLogInfo_merged.csv")

source.822e8bb3:
## Since the 'FAT' variable in weight_log_info has only two 
## entries & rest of the 65 entries are missing, at this point
## it doesn't seem to be useful for our analysis
weight_log_info_cleaned <- weight_log_info
weight_log_info_cleaned$Fat <- NULL
colnames(weight_log_info_cleaned)
source.8f73bc23:
## Converting timestamp to date time format 
## Then splitting to date and time

# hourly intensities
hourly_intensities$ActivityHour=as.POSIXct(hourly_intensities$ActivityHour,format="%m/%d/%Y %I:%M:%S %p", tz=Sys.timezone())
hourly_intensities$time <- format(hourly_intensities$ActivityHour,format = "%H:%M:%S")
hourly_intensities$date <- format(hourly_intensities$ActivityHour, format = "%m/%d/%y")

#hourly calories
hourly_calories$ActivityHour = as.POSIXct(hourly_calories$ActivityHour,format="%m/%d/%Y %I:%M:%S %p", tz=Sys.timezone())
hourly_calories$time <- format(hourly_calories$ActivityHour, format = "%H:%M:%S")
hourly_calories$date <- format(hourly_calories$ActivityHour, format = "%m/%d/%y")

#daily activity
daily_activity$ActivityDate = as.POSIXct(daily_activity$ActivityDate,format="%m/%d/%Y", tz=Sys.timezone())
daily_activity$date <- format(daily_activity$ActivityDate, format = "%m/%d/%y")

#sleep day
sleep_day_cleaned$SleepDay = as.POSIXct(sleep_day_cleaned$SleepDay,format="%m/%d/%Y %I:%M:%S %p", tz=Sys.timezone())
sleep_day_cleaned$time <- format(sleep_day_cleaned$SleepDay, format = "%H:%M:%S")
sleep_day_cleaned$date <- format(sleep_day_cleaned$SleepDay, format = "%m/%d/%y")

#weight log info
weight_log_info_cleaned$Date = as.POSIXct(weight_log_info_cleaned$Date,format="%m/%d/%Y %I:%M:%S %p", tz=Sys.timezone())
weight_log_info_cleaned$time <- format(weight_log_info_cleaned$Date, format = "%H:%M:%S")
weight_log_info_cleaned$date <- format(weight_log_info_cleaned$Date, format = "%m/%d/%y")
source.67a91075:
## Adding day of the week column in daily_activity data
daily_activity$day_of_the_week <- wday(daily_activity$ActivityDate,
                                      label=TRUE)
source.b413c586:
## Transform daily_activity data from wide to long format
daily_activity_long <- daily_activity %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = VeryActiveMinutes:SedentaryMinutes,
               names_to = "daily_activity_minute_type",
               values_to = "daily_activity_minute") %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = VeryActiveDistance:SedentaryActiveDistance,
               names_to = "daily_acitivity_distance_type",
               values_to = "daily_activity_distance")
source.4f5db6d4:
## Transform sleep_day data from wide to long format
sleep_day_long <- sleep_day_cleaned %>%
  mutate(TotalTimeNotAsleep = TotalTimeInBed - TotalMinutesAsleep) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(TotalTimeNotAsleep, TotalMinutesAsleep, TotalTimeInBed),
               names_to = "user_sleep_type",
               values_to = "time_count")

source.1dcc292c:
## What's the relationship between daily steps and 
# calories burned?
daily_steps_vs_calories_plot = ggplot(data=merged_data, 
                                      aes(x=TotalSteps, 
                                          y=Calories)) + 
  geom_point(shape=1) + geom_smooth(col="orange") + 
  theme_modern_rc() +
  labs(title="Total Steps vs. Calories",
       x="Total Steps",
       y="Calories",
       caption="Source: Fitbit Fitness Tracker Dataset published on Kaggle by Möbius") 

print(daily_steps_vs_calories_plot)
source.f7df11d0:
## What's the relationship between minutes asleep and time in
# bed?
ggplot(data=merged_data, aes(x=TotalMinutesAsleep, y=TotalTimeInBed)) + 
  geom_point(col="red") + stat_smooth(method = 'lm', col="green") + 
  theme_modern_rc() +
  labs(title="Total Minutes Asleep vs. Total Time In Bed",
       caption="Source: Fitbit Fitness Tracker Dataset published on Kaggle by Möbius",
       x="Total Minutes Asleep",
       y="Total Time In Bed")
source.8d856431:
## What's the relationship between total minutes asleep and
# sedentary minutes?
ggplot(data=merged_data, aes(x=TotalMinutesAsleep,
                             y=SedentaryMinutes)) +
  xlab("Total Minutes Asleep") + ylab("Sedentary Minutes") + 
  geom_point(shape=1,col="purple") + geom_smooth(col="yellow") +
  theme_modern_rc() + 
  labs(title="Minutes Asleep vs. Sedentary Minutes",
       caption="Source: Fitbit Fitness Tracker Dataset published on Kaggle by Möbius")
source.32592233:
## Are there any hours of the day when the participants are more
# active?
intensity_over_time <- hourly_intensities %>%
  group_by(time) %>%
  drop_na() %>%
  summarise(average_total_intensity = mean(TotalIntensity))

ggplot(data=intensity_over_time, aes(x=time, y=average_total_intensity,fill=..y..)) +
  xlab("Time(24 hrs)") + ylab("Average Total Intensity") + 
  geom_histogram(stat="identity") +
  scale_fill_gradient("Avg_Total_Intensity", low = "green", high = "red") +
  theme_modern_rc() + 
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90), legend.position = "none") +
  labs(title="Average Total Intensity vs. Time",
       caption="Source: Fitbit Fitness Tracker Dataset published on Kaggle by Möbius")
source.b45c1270:
## When in the week are participants more active and inactive?
daily_activity_temp <- daily_activity %>%
  mutate(TotalActiveMinutes = VeryActiveMinutes + 
                              FairlyActiveMinutes +
                              LightlyActiveMinutes)

avg_very_active_mins <- daily_activity_temp %>%
  group_by(day_of_the_week) %>%
  summarise_at(vars(VeryActiveMinutes),
               list(VeryActiveMinutes = mean))

avg_fairly_active_mins <- daily_activity_temp %>%
  group_by(day_of_the_week) %>%
  summarise_at(vars(FairlyActiveMinutes),
               list(FairlyActiveMinutes = mean))

avg_lightly_active_mins <- daily_activity_temp %>%
  group_by(day_of_the_week) %>%
  summarise_at(vars(LightlyActiveMinutes),
               list(LightlyActiveMinutes = mean))

avg_total_active_mins <- daily_activity_temp %>%
  group_by(day_of_the_week) %>%
  summarise_at(vars(TotalActiveMinutes),
               list(TotalActiveMinutes = mean))

avg_activity_mins <- merge(avg_very_active_mins,
                           avg_fairly_active_mins,
                           by=c("day_of_the_week"))

avg_activity_mins_2 <- merge(avg_activity_mins,
                             avg_lightly_active_mins,
                             by=c("day_of_the_week"))

very_active_mins_chart <- ggplot(avg_activity_mins_2, 
                                 aes(x=day_of_the_week,
                                     y=VeryActiveMinutes, 
                                     group=1))+
  geom_line(color = "green")+
  geom_point()+
  labs(title="Average Very Active Minutes by Weekdays",
       x= "Day Of The Week", y="Daily Very Active Minutes")+
  #labs(title = "Health Condition of Weight Tracking Users",
       #subtitle = "Propotion of participants in each body mass index group",
       #caption = "Source: Fitbit Fitness Tracker Dataset published on Kaggle by Möbius")+ 
  geom_text(aes(label=round(VeryActiveMinutes, digits=0), 
                hjust=-0.75, vjust=0.2),size=3,color = "black")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size=11), 
        text = element_text(size=10), 
        axis.text.x = element_text(angle=35, hjust=1))

fairly_active_mins_chart <- ggplot(avg_activity_mins_2, 
                                   aes(x=day_of_the_week,
                                       y=FairlyActiveMinutes, 
                                       group=1))+
  geom_line(color = "brown1")+
  geom_point()+
  labs(title="Average Fairly Active Minutes by Weekdays", 
       x= "Day Of The Week", y="Daily Fairly Active Minutes")+
  geom_text(aes(label=round(FairlyActiveMinutes, digits=0), 
                hjust=-.75, vjust=0.75),size=3.0,color = "black")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size=11), 
        text = element_text(size=10), 
        axis.text.x = element_text(angle=35, hjust=1))

lightly_active_mins_chart <- ggplot(avg_activity_mins_2, 
                                    aes(x=day_of_the_week,
                                        y=LightlyActiveMinutes, 
                                        group=1))+
  geom_line(color = "darkgoldenrod1")+
  geom_point()+
  labs(title="Average Lightly Active Minutes by Weekdays", 
       x= "Day Of The Week", y="Daily Lightly Active Minutes")+
  geom_text(aes(label=round(LightlyActiveMinutes, digits=0), 
                    hjust=-0.5, vjust=0.75),size=3,color = "black")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size=11), 
        text = element_text(size=10), 
        axis.text.x = element_text(angle=35, hjust=1))

total_daily_active_mins_chart <- ggplot(avg_total_active_mins, 
                                        aes(x=day_of_the_week,
                                            y=TotalActiveMinutes, 
                                            group=1))+
  geom_line(color = "purple")+
  geom_point()+
  labs(title="Average Total Active Minutes by Weekdays", 
       x= "Day Of The Week", y="Daily Total Active Minutes")+
  geom_text(aes(label=round(TotalActiveMinutes, digits=0), 
                 hjust=-0.1, vjust=0.9),
            size=3, 
            color = "black")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size=11), 
        text = element_text(size=10), 
        axis.text.x = element_text(angle=35, hjust=1))

main_title <- grid::textGrob("Average Active Minutes Per Day By Type Of Activity Intensity", 
                        gp=grid::gpar(fontsize=15, fontface='bold'))
caption <- grid::textGrob("Source: Fitbit Fitness Tracker Dataset published on Kaggle by Möbius", 
                            gp=grid::gpar(fontsize=7))

grid.arrange(very_active_mins_chart, fairly_active_mins_chart, 
             lightly_active_mins_chart,
             total_daily_active_mins_chart,
             top = main_title,
             bottom = caption,
             nrow = 2)
source.783458f0:
## Explore the health condition of the participants
users_bmi_summary <- weight_log_info_cleaned %>%
  group_by(Id) %>%
  summarise(latest_bmi = tail(BMI, 1))

users_bmi_summary <- users_bmi_summary %>%
  mutate(weight_standard = case_when(latest_bmi < 18.5 ~ "Underweight", 
                                    latest_bmi >= 18.5 & latest_bmi <= 24.9 ~ "Healthy Weight", 
                                    latest_bmi >= 25 & latest_bmi <30 ~ "Overweight", 
                                    latest_bmi >= 30 ~ "Obese"))

users_bmi_percentage <- users_bmi_summary %>%
  group_by(weight_standard) %>%
  summarise(Count = n())

users_bmi_percentage <- users_bmi_percentage %>%
  mutate(Percentage = (Count/8)*100)

users_health_condition_chart <- ggplot(data = users_bmi_percentage, 
                                       aes(x = "", y = Count, 
                                           fill = weight_standard)) + 
  #scale_colour_discrete(name="Weight Standard") +
  guides(fill=guide_legend(title="Weight Standard"))+
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", width = 1, color="white") + 
  geom_text(aes(label = paste(Percentage, "%")), 
            position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5),
            color = "white") + 
  coord_polar("y", start = 0) + theme_void() + 
  scale_fill_brewer(palette="Set1") +
  labs(title = "Health Condition of Weight Tracking Users",
       subtitle = "Propotion of participants in each body mass index group",
       caption = "Source: Fitbit Fitness Tracker Dataset published on Kaggle by Möbius")+
  theme(plot.title=element_text(size=20,face="bold"),
        plot.subtitle=element_text(size=12),
        legend.position = c(.99, .99),
        legend.justification = c("right", "top"),
        legend.box.just = "right",
        legend.box.background = element_rect(),
        legend.margin = margin(6, 6, 6, 6),
        legend.key = element_rect(colour = "black"),
        legend.title = element_text(face = "bold"))

plot(users_health_condition_chart)
source.72c45bc8:
### Ask ##### Business Task

To identify potential opportunities for growth and recommendations to influence improvement in Bellabeat marketing strategy based on trends observed in smart device usage.

##### Stakeholders of the company 1. Chief Creative Officer 2. Director of Marketing 3. Executive Team
source.81d64a69:
##### Aggregate Dataset

Before beginning to visualize the trends and patterns we observed above, I'm going to merge(inner join) daily activity and sleep on columns 'Id' and 'date'.
source.5d8b14fb:
Looking at the above histogram, I clearly notice that the participants seem to be most active between 5:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m.

We could use the above insight to send notification to the users of Bellabeat app to remind and motivate them to go for a run or workout.
source.e04ba5ad: ##### What trends or relationships did you find in the data? 1. **Average total steps** per day are **7638** which is little **less than recommended daily 10,000 steps** according to CDC research, they found that taking 8,000 steps per day was associated with a 51% lower risk for all-cause mortality and taking 12000 steps per dat was associated with a 65% lower risk compared with taking 4,000 steps. 2. **Average sedentary time** is **16 hours** or **991 mins**. 3. **Majority** of participants **conduct light active movement** on daily basis for about **3 hours or 193 mins on average**. 4. **75% of the users** still **conduct very active movement for about 32 minutes per day** and **some of those very active participants** conduct high intensity activity for **max of 210 mins in comparision to an average of 21 mins**. 5. Participants consume **97 calories per hour on average**. 6. Participants **sleep** 1 time for about **7 hours or 419.2 mins on average**. 7. Having an **average BMI of 25.19** which falls in the BMI index range of 25 - 29.9 is **considered overweight accoring to U.S. Department of Health and Human Services**. Note: weightLogInfo_merged.csv only has 67 observations. Hence, having more samples would help in justifying above assumption.
source.08fc5220: Looking at the above scatter plot, I clearly see positive correlation between Total Steps taken and Calories burned, i.e., the more active the participants are the more calories they burned.
source.0b1dc2dc:
Looking at the above line plot, I clearly notice that majority of participants are more active on Tuesday and leat active on Sunday.

On average, participants have the most active minutes on Tuesday with -

1. Very Active Mins - 23 2. Fairly Active Mins - 14 3. Lightly Active Mins - 197 4. Total Active Mins - 235

On average, participants have the least active minutes on Sunday with -

1. Very Active Mins - 20 2. Fairly Active Mins - 15 3. Lightly Active Mins - 174 4. Total Active Mins - 208

We could use the above insight to send notification to users of Bellabeat to conduct HIIT(High-Intensity Interval Training) workout on Tuesdays.
source.c8b1fd11:
### Introduction ##### About The Company

Bellabeat, a high-tech manufacturer of health-focused products for women. Bellabeat is a successful small company, but they’ve potential to become a larger player in the global smart device market. Urška Sršen, cofounder and Chief Creative Officer of Bellabeat, believes that analyzing smart device fitness data could help unlock new growth opportunities for the company.

##### Company's Products 1. **Bellabeat App**: The Bellabeat app provides users with health data related to their activity, sleep, stress, menstrual cycle, and mindfulness habits. It connects to their line of smart wellness product. 2. **Leaf**: Bellabeat’s classic wellness tracker can be worn as a bracelet, necklace, or clip. It connects to the Bellabeat app to track activity, sleep or stress. 3. **Time**: This wellness watch combines the timeless look of classic timepiece with smart technology to track user activity, sleep and stress. It connects to the Bellabeat app to provide you with insights into your daily wellness. 4. **Spring**: This is a water bottle that tracks daily water intake using smart technology to ensure that you’re appropriately hydrated throughout the day. It connects to the Bellabeat app to track your hydration levels. 5. **Bellabeat Membership**: Bellabeat also offers a subscription-based membership program for users. It gives users 24/7 access to fully personalized guidance on nutrition, activity, sleep, health and beauty and mindfulness based on their lifestyle and goals. ##### Purpose of this case study

I will be completing this analysis using six phases of the data analysis process: Ask, Prepare, Process, Analyze, Share and Act.
source.6e834ed8:
### Analyze ##### Has your data been properly formatted?

Yes, took care of missing values, duplicate entries found in couple of the data sets. Changed timestamp data into date time format and then split them into individual columns, and added a new column for day of the week and transformed two of the datasets from wide to long format.
source.4db6f115:
Looking at the above pie chart, I clearly notice that 50% of the participants are overweight and 12.5% are Obese.

Just as an idea: Bellabeat app can send notification to these participants to remind and motivate them to move and suggest healthy diet recipes.
source.2224ae4e: Thank you for your interest in this case study.
source.19011341:
The above figures tell us about the number of participants in each datasets with 33 participants in daily activity, hourly calories and intentsities, 24 participants in users sleep day and 8 participants in the users weight log info.

It seems like there maybe more participants in the daily activity than sleep day dataset.
source.f273496d:
### Act ##### What next steps would you or your stakeholders take based on your findings?

Collecting data from existing users of Bellabeat(with their consent) over a more appropriate time period to find out how they're using Bellabeat app paired with its smart devices(like watch, necklace, bracelet, clip or bottle) and look for areas of opportunity within the product to explore further and beyond.

##### What is your final conclusion based on your analysis?

Trends or relationships discovered while conducting the analysis provided valuable insight into how consumers used their fitness tracking devices; however, take a note that insights gained throughout this analysis is limited due to several factors - sample population is relatively small, data collected from anonymous participants, since there is no relevant information such as gender, location, and lifestyle.
source.6429ad62:
### Recommendations

Bellabeat has grown rapidly as a tech-driven wellness company for women. Collecting data on activity, sleep, stress and general health has allowed Bellabeat to empower women with knowledge about their own health and habits.

After conducting analysis on FitBit Fitness Tracker Data, I discovered few interesting trends and patterns that would help influence Bellabeat marketing strategy.

##### Target Audience

Women who work full-time jobs have been observed to spend most of their time on the computer(according to sedentary time data and hourly intensity data).These women do some light activity to stay healthy(according to activity intensity analysis). In order to develop healthy habits and motivation to keep going,they might need some knowledge on how to improve their everyday activity.

##### Ideas for the Bellabeat app paired with smart devices

Bellabeat App: It Bact as a guide almost like a friend that empowers and nurtures women to balance personal and professional life and develop healthly habits and routines by educating and motivating them through daily recommendations.

1. Average total steps per day are 7638 which is little less than recommended daily 10,000 steps according to CDC research, they found that taking 8,000 steps per day was associated with a 51% lower risk for all-cause mortality and taking 12000 steps per dat was associated with a 65% lower risk compared with taking 4,000 steps. **Bellabeat can encourage its users to take atleast 8,000 steps per day explaining the benefits for the health via its app and track with help of wellness watch or leaf accessories**. 2. 50% of the participants are overweight and 12.5% are Obese. For these group of users in order to loose weight in healthly manner, **Bellabeat can control daily consumption where the app can suggest filling low-calorie meals**. 3. Participants sleep 1 time for about 7 hours or 419.2 mins on average. **Bellabeat can send notification through its app to go to bed and reduce exporsure to blue light and motivate users to atleast get 8 hours of quality sleep**. 4. Since participants are most active between 5 p.m. to 7 p.m. - assuming people go to the gym or for a walk after finishing work, **Bellabeat can use this insight to remind and motivate users to either go for walk or workout through its app**. 5. As most of the participants have most active Tuesday, Bellabeat could notify its users to conduct very active intensity movement. On the other hand, during least active Sunday's, **Bellabeat could notify its users to reduce sedentary minutes and atleast conduct light active movement**.
source.004ec92c:
### Prepare ##### About the dataset

FitBit Fitness Tracker Dataset(CC0: Public Domain) made available through Mobius. These datasets were generated by respondents to a distributed survey via Amazon Mechanical Turk between 2016-03-12 to 2016-05-12. This Kaggle dataset contains personal fitness tracker from thirty Fitbit users. Thirty eligible Fitbit users consented to the submission of personal tracker data, including minute-level output for physical activity, heart rate, and sleep monitoring. It includes information about daily activity, steps and heart rate that can be used to explore user’s habits.

##### How is the data organized?

FitBit Fitness Tracker Dataset is organized in wide format.

##### Are there issues with bias or credibility in this data? Does your data ROCCC? 1. Reliability: Low, high potential of sample size being biased 2. Original: Low, relying on 3rd party data 3. Comprehensive: Moderate, comprehensive for the sample size and duration of the study 4. Current: Low, data is from 2016, which is now size years old 5. Cited: High, data is cited ##### How are you addressing licensing, privacy, security, and accessibility?

Referencing original as well as the Kaggle profile dataset where the data is obtained through Mobius.

Creating data analysis report with RStudio and R Markdown for accessibility and usability.
source.685c6895:
Looking at the above scatter plot, I clearly notive linear relaitonship between Total Minutes Asleep and Total Time in Bed.

Hence, if the users of Bellabeat would want to improve their quality of sleep, they should consider getting notified to go to sleep to build consistent sleeping pattern, reduce exposure to blue-light.
source.2c4f53c2:
### Process ##### What tools are you choosing and why?

I chose to use the following datasets: dailyActivity_merged.csv, hourlyCalories_merged.csv, hourlyIntensities_merged.csv, sleepDay_merged.csv, weightLogInfo_merged.csv because they're almost relevant with Bellabeat app and it's smart devices.

To conduct the analysis I'm using certain R Packages like "tidyverse", "dplyr", "ggplot2", "tidyr", "lubridate", "gridExtra".

##### Have you ensured your data's integrity?

Yes, I've decided to proceed with FitBit Fitness Tracker Dataset as it could provide valuable insights that closely resembles to Bellabeat app and it's smart devices. Hence, we will be looking at pertinent data in order to conduct sound analysis for this business case.

##### How can you verify that your data is clean and ready to analyze?

Reviewing FitBit Fitness Tracker Dataset for any duplicates, missing values, ensuring data is consistent, having an eye for outliers and transforming data into more appropriate data types useful for our analysis.

##### Have you documented your cleaning process so you can review and share those results?

Yes, below I've noted down few changes made while cleaning, formatting and manipulating few of the FitBit Fitness Tracker Datasets:

1. Removed 3 duplicate entries found in sleep_data.csv. 2. Removed "Fat" variable/category from the weight_log_info.csv since it had only 2 valid entries and rest of the 65 entries were missing, which case it wouldn't be much of use for our analysis. 3. Spotted an issue with timestamp data, decided to convert it into date time format and then split it into date and time. 4. Added day of the week column in daily_activity.csv. 5. Transformed daily_activity.csv and sleep_day_cleaned.csv from wide to long format.
source.832bcc6a:
Looking at the above scatter plot,I notice negative relationship between Sedentary Minutes and Total Minutes Asleep.

However, if Bellabeat users want to get relaxing goodnight sleep, Bellabeat app can send notification to reduce sedentary time.
